During the past few weeks the
business staff of the Barnstormers,
under the direction of Harold
Schwartz, business manager, has
been making final arrangements for
the sale of tickets. They are now
able to make definite statements as
to the time and place of the ticket
vending.
Due to the fact that this year's
production, "The Black Flamingo,"
is to be given on December 5th and
6th, a date appreciably earlier than
that of former years, the tickets
will go on sale November 15th,
simultaneously at Albaugh's Ticket
Agency, 8 East Lexington Street,
Baltimore, and at Levering Hall.

Circulation Manager
GEORGE W. LA MONT,'32

The price of admission ranges
from $.50 to $2.50. Orchestra seats
will be $2.00 and there will be some
at $1.50. Possession of a Student's Activities Card entitles the
holder to one ($2.00) orchestra
seat. Inasmuch as the production
of this year's play is less than one
month off, the business board
wishes to urge all who contemplate
attending to make - their reservations as soon as pOssible.
The Barnstormers' dance will
take place each night after the play
at the Knights of Pythias Hall.
Contrary to precedent, the price
of admission will be $1.00, even for
those holding reserved seat stubs.

Md. Institute Holds Contest

As has happened in former times,
the Maryland Institute of Art is
running their annual Barnstormer
poster contest. Placards of many
talented artists are entered in this
contest and from it the dramatic
club is usually able to select an attractive poster for advertising purposes.
The quota of Freshmen candidates for the business staff of the
Barnstormers is by no means full
at this time, it was learned. Daniel
Miller and Walter Kneip, assistant
business managers in charge of
candidates, wish to urge any man
who have any ability in the field of
taking care of the business or advertising end of a dramatic organization to see them about trying out
for the club.
The Barnstormers has always
been considered one of the most important organizations on the
campus and membership on the
business staff of the club is by no
means deemed inferior to the dramatic staff.

EDI1 ORIALS
A WORTHY CAUSE

J

N SPITE of opposition, the Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. usuallly
succeeds in accomplishing whatever it sets out to do. We hope this
will be the case in the recently organized drive for funds. Two years
ago, Hopkins needed a student activities building badly, but the
University was not in a position to erect one. The Y. M. C. A. undertook the task, and with the handicap of a skeptical student body,
conducted a drive for funds. Many of the contributions were made
because the Y. M. C. A. was backing the drive, and not solely for
the benefit of activities at Johns Hopkins University. We can hardly
see how any fairminded person can take any attitude but that of
thanking the Y. M. C. A. for its philanthropy.
Last year numerous experiments had to be made in Levering
Hall. A considerable deficit resulted. We can hardly say that this
was due to mismanagement. If at the end of this year the Y. M. C. A.
again has a deficit, charges of mismanagement might be expected.
We are of the opinion that prices in the cafeteria should be reduced,
but otherwise Levering Hall seems to be efficiently managed.
The Y. M. C. A. goes to a great expense in furnishing things
needed by the student. The money contributed by the Student Activities Council by no means pays for these various services. Outside
contribution by friends of the "Y" pay for all purely Y. M. C. A.
activities, and for the major part of the services rendered the campus
as a whole. Levering Hall is open to all students for purposes of
recreation and study, or for business and social meetings. The library
contains magazines, newspapers, and some current fiction. Cards and
checkers are furnished for all who desire them. Rooms for meetings
or dances may be procured upon notice gratuitously. For these services
alone the Y. M. C. A. deserves liberal contributions frbm the students.
For those interested in activities, the "Y" has done even more.
The offices have been built and furnished by the Y. M. C. A. and are
now kept in repair by that organization. Other special groups are
also benefited. The Rooming Bureau gives free service to out-of-town
students. Foreign students are entertained by the "Y". Although the
handbook is made to pay for itself, were it not for the activity of
the Y, no such volume would be published.
We have endeavored to previously point out that the Y. M. C. A.
is not financially compensated by the student for these various activities, and we are of the firm conviction that the "Y" has the right to put
on such a drive and to expect that it will meet with the utmost
success.

DEBATING
OHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY has always stood among the
leading institutions of the country in scholarship. It seems quite
unusual and indeed regretable that so little interest is manifested in
debating, an activity obviously of great intellectual stimulation. In the
past, debating was one of the leading activities on the campus, and
there is no plausible reason why it should not still be. The lack of
interest has been so apparent that the officials of the University will
no longer sponsor inter-college debates.
With an increased undergraduate enrollment, an increased interest
was expected this year. On the contrary, less interest has been shown
than ever before. Can it be that students do not care to be intellectually stimulated, and prefer to use their minds as little as necessary?

IS the integrated expression of
many exceptional qualities."
Is Endogenous Growth
"The quality of leadership is an
endogenous growth," said the lecturer. "There must be confidence
in yourself and in the children of
your brain; the courage to accept
responsibility and to act upon matured conclusions; the willingness
to pay the price of leadership, and
hard continuous work."
There should always be a definite
goal toward which all effort is directed, he further said. "We may
never reach the goal, but we shall
certainly go further than he who is
sauntering without one."
Leaders do not wait for the arrival of opportunity, said Dr. Little,
even though alert to seize it when
it presents itself, but go out to meet
it, and create it if it's not present.
Heavy Prices Paid

Years of poverty, and physical
limitations and disabilities are two
of the outstanding prices paid by
both men and women in the quest
for leadership in varied fields.
"The great laboratory leaders
have always been distinguished for
their power of stimulating originality ill others. The influence of
Ira Remsen pervaded the Johns
Hopkins laboratories, and his books
and Remsen's Journal carried that
influence far afield. He led one student to the discovery of saccharin.
He developed leadership in others
as evidenced by many of the names
appearing with his own in the list
of 58 papers of which he was coauthor," declared Dr. Little.
Everyone Potential Leader

Even though latent in the average man, it was said that there is
place and scope for leadership of
many grades and that the essential
qualities are present. The speaker
quoted Owen D. Young as having
asserted, "Basically, nearly all normal men are potential leaders," and

price of leadership, "99 out of 100
potential leaders fail to take their
proper place."
"Leadership is accorded to those
who have acquired an authoritative
mastery of some branch or knowledge, and who have developed those
personal qualities which command
respect and make for happy human
relations," declared the speaker.
Leadership An Attainment

"Although the grade of leadership which one may reach is largely
determined by circumstances and
endowment, leadership itself is an
attainment rather than a gift."
Dr. Little commended Francis
P. Garvin for endowing the Chair
of Chemical Education at Johns
Hopkins for the advancement in
the training of potential pioneers in
chemistry. In discussing the Fellowship plan, he pointed out that
every friend of chemistry is under
obligation to the donors whose
"vision and liberality have made
possible the realization of the plan."

First Matches to be With High
Schools

FRIED'S

George Darley is laying plans al-

ready for the basket ball season.
With the increase of interest in
the sport of wrestling at Hopkins
over forty men turned out at the
meeting held last Wednesday.
Among those present were Bob
Umberger, former luminary of the
mat at the local Y. M. C. A. The
captain of last year's wrestling
squad at the Columbia Grammar
School, Ted Stern, has appeared to
augment the strength of the Hopkins team, and as a coach the team
will profit by the services of Gus
Vasant, who last year in the national championship meets held in
Michigan came through second.
David Dolowitz was appointed
financial manager of the squad, and
he, in turn, appointed as his assistant Will Bloom, who has been associated with the football squad.
It is requested that all candidates
come out for practice, as in order
to fill up a few weak spaces in the
squad a group of men in the light
class is necessary. These weights
range from 110 to 140 pounds.
Practice is held every Tuesday and
Wednesday afternoon at 1 :00 and
at 4:00 at the Barn.
There is an incomplete schedule
in form which includes matches
with Poly and other local high
schools, although the manager is at
present negotiating with colleges of
the region for meetings. A tentative schedule will be announced in
a coming issue of the NEWSLETTER.

During the past few weeks the
business staff of the Barnstormers,
under the direction of Harold
Schwartz, business manager, has
been making final arrangements for
the sale of tickets. They are now
able to make definite statements as
to the time and place of the ticket
vending.
Due to the fact that this year's
production, "The Black Flamingo,"
is to be given on December 5th and
6th, a date appreciably earlier than
that of former years, the tickets
will go on sale November 15th,
simultaneously at Albaugh's Ticket
Agency, 8 East Lexington Street,
Baltimore, and at Levering Hall.

Circulation Manager
GEORGE W. LA MONT,'32

The price of admission ranges
from $.50 to $2.50. Orchestra seats
will be $2.00 and there will be some
at $1.50. Possession of a Student's Activities Card entitles the
holder to one ($2.00) orchestra
seat. Inasmuch as the production
of this year's play is less than one
month off, the business board
wishes to urge all who contemplate
attending to make - their reservations as soon as pOssible.
The Barnstormers' dance will
take place each night after the play
at the Knights of Pythias Hall.
Contrary to precedent, the price
of admission will be $1.00, even for
those holding reserved seat stubs.

Md. Institute Holds Contest

As has happened in former times,
the Maryland Institute of Art is
running their annual Barnstormer
poster contest. Placards of many
talented artists are entered in this
contest and from it the dramatic
club is usually able to select an attractive poster for advertising purposes.
The quota of Freshmen candidates for the business staff of the
Barnstormers is by no means full
at this time, it was learned. Daniel
Miller and Walter Kneip, assistant
business managers in charge of
candidates, wish to urge any man
who have any ability in the field of
taking care of the business or advertising end of a dramatic organization to see them about trying out
for the club.
The Barnstormers has always
been considered one of the most important organizations on the
campus and membership on the
business staff of the club is by no
means deemed inferior to the dramatic staff.

A WORTHY CAUSE

J

N SPITE of opposition, the Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. usuallly
succeeds in accomplishing whatever it sets out to do. We hope this
will be the case in the recently organized drive for funds. Two years
ago, Hopkins needed a student activities building badly, but the
University was not in a position to erect one. The Y. M. C. A. undertook the task, and with the handicap of a skeptical student body,
conducted a drive for funds. Many of the contributions were made
because the Y. M. C. A. was backing the drive, and not solely for
the benefit of activities at Johns Hopkins University. We can hardly
see how any fairminded person can take any attitude but that of
thanking the Y. M. C. A. for its philanthropy.
Last year numerous experiments had to be made in Levering
Hall. A considerable deficit resulted. We can hardly say that this
was due to mismanagement. If at the end of this year the Y. M. C. A.
again has a deficit, charges of mismanagement might be expected.
We are of the opinion that prices in the cafeteria should be reduced,
but otherwise Levering Hall seems to be efficiently managed.
The Y. M. C. A. goes to a great expense in furnishing things
needed by the student. The money contributed by the Student Activities Council by no means pays for these various services. Outside
contribution by friends of the "Y" pay for all purely Y. M. C. A.
activities, and for the major part of the services rendered the campus
as a whole. Levering Hall is open to all students for purposes of
recreation and study, or for business and social meetings. The library
contains magazines, newspapers, and some current fiction. Cards and
checkers are furnished for all who desire them. Rooms for meetings
or dances may be procured upon notice gratuitously. For these services
alone the Y. M. C. A. deserves liberal contributions frbm the students.
For those interested in activities, the "Y" has done even more.
The offices have been built and furnished by the Y. M. C. A. and are
now kept in repair by that organization. Other special groups are
also benefited. The Rooming Bureau gives free service to out-of-town
students. Foreign students are entertained by the "Y". Although the
handbook is made to pay for itself, were it not for the activity of
the Y, no such volume would be published.
We have endeavored to previously point out that the Y. M. C. A.
is not financially compensated by the student for these various activities, and we are of the firm conviction that the "Y" has the right to put
on such a drive and to expect that it will meet with the utmost
success.

DEBATING
OHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY has always stood among the
leading institutions of the country in scholarship. It seems quite
unusual and indeed regretable that so little interest is manifested in
debating, an activity obviously of great intellectual stimulation. In the
past, debating was one of the leading activities on the campus, and
there is no plausible reason why it should not still be. The lack of
interest has been so apparent that the officials of the University will
no longer sponsor inter-college debates.
With an increased undergraduate enrollment, an increased interest
was expected this year. On the contrary, less interest has been shown
than ever before. Can it be that students do not care to be intellectually stimulated, and prefer to use their minds as little as necessary?

Is Endogenous Growth
"The quality of leadership is an
endogenous growth," said the lecturer. "There must be confidence
in yourself and in the children of
your brain; the courage to accept
responsibility and to act upon matured conclusions; the willingness
to pay the price of leadership, and
hard continuous work."
There should always be a definite
goal toward which all effort is directed, he further said. "We may
never reach the goal, but we shall
certainly go further than he who is
sauntering without one."
Leaders do not wait for the arrival of opportunity, said Dr. Little,
even though alert to seize it when
it presents itself, but go out to meet
it, and create it if it's not present.
Heavy Prices Paid

Years of poverty, and physical
limitations and disabilities are two
of the outstanding prices paid by
both men and women in the quest
for leadership in varied fields.
"The great laboratory leaders
have always been distinguished for
their power of stimulating originality ill others. The influence of
Ira Remsen pervaded the Johns
Hopkins laboratories, and his books
and Remsen's Journal carried that
influence far afield. He led one student to the discovery of saccharin.
He developed leadership in others
as evidenced by many of the names
appearing with his own in the list
of 58 papers of which he was coauthor," declared Dr. Little.
Everyone Potential Leader

Even though latent in the average man, it was said that there is
place and scope for leadership of
many grades and that the essential
qualities are present. The speaker
quoted Owen D. Young as having
asserted, "Basically, nearly all normal men are potential leaders," and

price of leadership, "99 out of 100
potential leaders fail to take their
proper place."
"Leadership is accorded to those
who have acquired an authoritative
mastery of some branch or knowledge, and who have developed those
personal qualities which command
respect and make for happy human
relations," declared the speaker.
Leadership An Attainment

"Although the grade of leadership which one may reach is largely
determined by circumstances and
endowment, leadership itself is an
attainment rather than a gift."
Dr. Little commended Francis
P. Garvin for endowing the Chair
of Chemical Education at Johns
Hopkins for the advancement in
the training of potential pioneers in
chemistry. In discussing the Fellowship plan, he pointed out that
every friend of chemistry is under
obligation to the donors whose
"vision and liberality have made
possible the realization of the plan."

First Matches to be With High

FRIED'S

George Darley is laying plans al-

ready for the basket ball season.
With the increase of interest in
the sport of wrestling at Hopkins
over forty men turned out at the
meeting held last Wednesday.
Among those present were Bob
Umberger, former luminary of the
mat at the local Y. M. C. A. The
captain of last year's wrestling
squad at the Columbia Grammar
School, Ted Stern, has appeared to
augment the strength of the Hopkins team, and as a coach the team
will profit by the services of Gus
Vasant, who last year in the national championship meets held in
Michigan came through second.
David Dolowitz was appointed
financial manager of the squad, and
he, in turn, appointed as his assistant Will Bloom, who has been associated with the football squad.
It is requested that all candidates
come out for practice, as in order
to fill up a few weak spaces in the
squad a group of men in the light
class is necessary. These weights
range from 110 to 140 pounds.
Practice is held every Tuesday and
Wednesday afternoon at 1 :00 and
at 4:00 at the Barn.
There is an incomplete schedule
in form which includes matches
with Poly and other local high
schools, although the manager is at
present negotiating with colleges of
the region for meetings. A tentative schedule will be announced in
a coming issue of the NEWSLETTER.
